DOC.HEAD: Calls Jam US Military Switchboards in Hunt for Noriega
DOC.TEXT: After days of scouring Panama for Manuel Antonio Noriega, U.S. forces still don't have their quarry. But they do have a surplus of tips and rumors about the whereabouts of the fugitive general, thanks largely to the posting of a $1 million reward. The number of calls jamming U.S. military switchboards in Panama rose sharply on Wednesday in response to the White House's announcement that the money was available for anyone providing information leading to Noriega's capture. ``We got lots of nibbles. A lot of it turned out to be very bogus,'' said Rear Adm. Ted Sheafer, an intelligence specialist for the Joint Chiefs of Staff. Sheafer said callers reported sighting Noriega in at least 12 locations throughout Panama, 10 sites in Panama City and in three foreign countries _ Colombia, the Dominican Republic and Mexico. U.S. officials said, however, they believed Noriega had not left the country. Noriega's wanted poster ``will be in every post office in town,'' President Bush told reporters jokingly at a White House news conference Thursday, adding that ``that's $1 million bucks I'd be very happy to sign the check for.'' But Noriega proved an elusive target for the commando forces and intelligence analysts who set their traps for him. After rumors spread that Noriega or other members of the Panamanian Defense Forces high command were in the Nicaraguan and Cuban embassies, U.S. troops in armored personnel carriers surrounded the two missions. But despite the massive dragnet for Noriega, aided by a force of 24,000 troops, U.S. hopes lay almost solely on reliable intelligence information. ``We're looking for him very hard,'' said Lt. Gen. Tom Kelly, the Pentagon's operations chief. ``Of course, that's all contingent on intelligence.'' American interrogators questioned hundreds of captured Panamanian soldiers for clues about Noriega's plans, said one official who asked not to be named. Kelly said American forces were ``turning on all our looking, listening, and hearing devices to see if we can't pick'' up Noriega. The man in charge of the Panama strike, Lt. Gen. Carl W. Stiner, who now commands the 18th Airborne Corps at Fort Bragg, N.C., formerly headed the U.S. Special Operations Forces which are tasked with commando-style activities. Special Forces units reportedly were deployed to look for Noriega, aided by infantry troops of the 7th Army which are especially trained for urban warfare. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater conceded that finding Noriega in Panama City would be difficult. ``In a city of a million people, it's not hard to hide out,'' he said. Pentagon officials also held out the possibility that U.S. troops may have to stalk Noriega or his loyalists in Panama's jungles. Although he is vastly outnumbered by the 24,000-strong U.S. strike force, Noriega _ former head of military intelligence and paid informer for the CIA in the 1970s _ is hard to outmaneuver, officials said. ``He's a crafty devil, as you know,'' said Kelly. ``He grew up in a very tough academy, so he's been used to this for many years.'' It was unclear how many forces Noriega still has under his command although Sheafer said, ``We do not think he is effectively in command of anything at this time.'' Bush said he would not be satisfied until Noriega was brought to justice in the United States, and would keep up the search as long as it took. But Noriega has vowed to fight to his death, and those who know him well say he would resist capture at all costs. Said reserve Col. Charles Stone, who served in Panama until 1987 and often met with Noriega: ``I think before he'd face that, he'd take his own life.''
